title: Integration Studio based Gmail integration
content:
Overview

The Gmail integration feature enables you to automatically create requests from emails sent to a specific Gmail account. You can customize it to create incidents, problems, and changes. You can also allow external users to raise records by configuring the scenario.

If you configure Gmail integration for automatic record creation, remember that the email senders will also receive notifications about updates to their records, including solutions to their requests. Make sure that your configure does not expose sensitive information.
The Gmail integration feature is supported on versions 24.4.1 and above.

This email integration uses Gmail API and OAuth 2.0 Authorization Grant Type for authentication.

Prerequisites

Before you set up Gmail integration, make sure the following requirements are fulfilled.

  • Gmail Account: Make sure you have created a Gmail account.
  • Service Management System: Verify that your service management system can send and receive messages from Google Cloud Platform.

Enable OAuth 2.0 on Google Cloud Platform

Complete the following tasks to enable OAuth 2.0 on Google Cloud Platform.

  1. Go to https://console.cloud.google.com/apis URL to open the Google Cloud Console.
  2. Create or select a project.
    1. Click the NEW PROJECT button to create a new project.
    2. Switch to new project.
  3. Enable Gmail API
    1. Go to APIs & Services -> Enabled APIs & services.
    2. Click + ENABLE APIS AND SERVICES button then select Gmail API.
    3. Click Enable button.
  4. Configure application for OAuth2
    1. Go to APIs & Services -> OAuth content screen.
    2. Provide  App name and User support emails.
    3. Provide Developer contact information and click SAVE AND CONTINUE.
    4. On the Scopes configuration page click SAVE AND CONTINUE.
    5. On the Test users configuration page, click + ADD USERS button then provide the email will used for logging in on Service Management endpoint configuration page.
  5. Configure credentials for OAuth2
    1. Go to APIs & Services -> Credentials.
    2. Click + CREATE CREDENTIALS -> API Key.
      1. Create a key and make a note of the API Key value.
    3. Click + CREATE CREDENTIALS -> OAuth client ID.
      1. Select Web application for Application type.
      2. Click + ADD URI under Authorized redirect URI, and enter the URL for oauth-callback. Refer to the following example for the URL Replace the placeholders <SERVICE_MANAGEMENT_FQDN> and <SMAX_TENANT_ID> with values from your environment. 
        https://<SERVICE_MANAGEMENT_FQDN>/rest/<SMAX_TENANT_ID>/opb/oauth/callback
      3. Click Save.
      4. Make a note of the Client ID and Client secret displayed on the pop up window.

Set up the integration

To set up the email integration, complete the following tasks.

Create integration user

We recommend creating a dedicated integration user for each integration.

  1. Create an integration user. See How to create an integration user.
  2. Log in to Agent Interface as the tenant admin.
  3. Navigate to Administration > Master Data > People, locate the integration user, and then assign the proper roles to access the required modules. At a minimum, the role should have the following permissions:

    To integrate with the Request record type:
    • The On-Premise Bridge/Integration Administrator permission
    • The View permission to the Person record type
    • The View and Create permissions to the Request record type
    To integrate with the Incident, Problem, or Change record types:
    • The View permission to the Person record type
    • The View and Create permissions to the relevant record type
    To allow non-Service Management users to create records by email, if needed:
    • The View and Create permissions to the Person record type
    Alternatively, add the Tenant Admin role to grant general access.

Create an endpoint

To create an endpoint using the Rest Executor 2.0 endpoint type, complete the following steps.

  1. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Endpoints.
  2. Click Add.
  3. Select Rest Executor 2.0 as the endpoint type.
  4. Enter a name for the endpoint (for example, gmail-endpoint), and then click Add. The system creates the endpoint.
  5. Click Configure and complete the following fields:
    Section Field Value
    General configuration Agent Select Agentless for a direct connection to the Gamil API.
    Authentication type Select OAuth 2.0.
    Protocol Select https.
    Base URL Enter the base URL of the Gmail API: https://gmail.googleapis.com/.
    Certificate type Optional.
    Certificate format Optional.
    Server certificate Optional.
    Enable email notification for expired token Optional.
    Recipients Optional.
    Get Token configuration Grant Type

    Authorization Code.
    Client ID The application ID.
    Client Secret The client's secret value for the app.
    Authorization URL https://accounts.google.com/o/oauth2/auth?access_type=offline&prompt=consent.
    Redirect URL Automatically generated.
    Token URL https://oauth2.googleapis.com/token.
    Scope

    https://mail.google.com/. For the full list of required OAuth scopes scope, see Actions table in the Gmail Connector API.  This field can take one or more URLs separated by spaces.
    State Optional.
    Send client Id and secret In body.
  6. Click Get token, and then complete the login and consent process.
  7. If your endpoint configuration is correct, you will see the Available status in the Token status section after the process is finished.
  8. Click Save.

Create an integration

Perform the following steps to create an integration based on the Gmail connector.

Create a dedicated integration for each record type.
  1. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Studio.
  2. Click New, enter the name of your integration, and then click Save. The system displays the Integration page.
  3. In the Details section, configure the integration user you created for the current Service Management system and activate the integration.
  4. In the Connector-Endpoint mappings section, click Add to add a mapping.
  5. Select Gmail API (under Google) as the connector, select the gmail endpoint created earlier, and then enter an alias for the mapping.
  6. Click Save.
